content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number. For time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, a particle moves in the <math alttext="x y" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mspace> </mspace> <mi>y</mi> </math>-plane with position <math alttext="x of t, comma, y of t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>,</mo> <mi>y</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, where <math alttext="x of t equals, t plus the cosine of t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mi>cos</mi> <mo>⁡</mo> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, t squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mi>sin</mi> <mo>⁡</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"> </mspace> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 6" overflow="scroll"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>6</mn> </math>, <math alttext="y of 6, equals 4" overflow="scroll"> <mi>y</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>6</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> </math>. (a) Find the speed of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Show the setup for your calculations.

(a) Find the speed of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Show the setup for your calculations.

(b) Find the total distance traveled by the particle over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 6" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>6</mn> </math>. Show the setup for your calculations.
(c) Write an equation for the line tangent to the path of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 6" overflow="scroll"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>6</mn> </math>.

(d) Find the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Show the setup for your calculations.

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.1: (BC ONLY) Defining and Differentiating Parametric Equations

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
